definitions: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: This biome includes open-ocean and unprotected coastal ecosystems, characterized by exposure to wave action, tidal fluctuation, and ocean currents as well as systems that largely resemble these. Water in the marine biome is generally within the salinity range of seawater: 30 to 38 ppt.
definitions: An aquatic biome which is determined by a marine water body.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem|freshwater ecosystem

comments: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large rivers" (e.g. the Mekong river) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-river-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.
definitions: A freshwater river biome which is determined by a large river.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|large river biome|freshwater river biome|aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem|freshwater ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|river|stream|watercourse|freshwater river|fresh water|fresh water body|liquid environmental material|freshwater stream

comments: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large river headwaters" (e.g. the Upper Amazon headwaters) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-river-headwater-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.
definitions: A freshwater river biome which is determined by the headwaters of a large river.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|freshwater river biome|aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem|large river headwater biome|freshwater ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|headwater|depressed landform|freshwater biome|large river biome|river|stream|watercourse|freshwater river biome|structural basin|freshwater river|slope|fresh water|aquatic biome|fresh water body|liquid environmental material|freshwater stream|aquatic ecosystem|freshwater ecosystem
part of: freshwater biome|large river biome|freshwater river biome|aquatic biome|fresh water body|aquatic ecosystem|freshwater ecosystem

comments: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large river deltas" (e.g. the Niger river delta) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-river-delta-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.
definitions: A freshwater river biome which is determined by the delta of a large river.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|freshwater river biome|aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem|large river delta biome|freshwater ecosystem
overlaps: stream mouth|river mouth|liquid water|delta|mouth|freshwater biome|large river biome|river|stream|watercourse|freshwater river biome|freshwater river|fresh water|aquatic biome|fresh water body|liquid environmental material|freshwater stream|aquatic ecosystem|freshwater ecosystem
part of: freshwater biome|large river biome|freshwater river biome|aquatic biome|fresh water body|aquatic ecosystem|freshwater ecosystem

comments: "Small" is ambiguous. For details on "Small rivers" (e.g. the Salween river) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/small-river-ecosystems. This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.
definitions: A freshwater river biome which is determined by a small river.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|freshwater river biome|aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem|small river biome|freshwater ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|river|stream|watercourse|freshwater river|fresh water|fresh water body|liquid environmental material|freshwater stream

comments: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large lakes" (e.g. African rift lakes) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-lake-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.
definitions: A freshwater biome which is determined by a large lake.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|aquatic biome|freshwater lake biome|aquatic ecosystem|large freshwater lake biome|freshwater ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|lake|freshwater lake|fresh water|fresh water body|liquid environmental material

comments: "Small" is ambiguous. For details on "Small lakes" (e.g. Cameroon crater lakes)  see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/small-lake-ecosystems. This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.
definitions: A freshwater lake biome which is determined by a small lake.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|aquatic biome|freshwater lake biome|aquatic ecosystem|small freshwater lake biome|freshwater ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|lake|freshwater lake|fresh water|fresh water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: A biome which has little permanent surface water and a low relative abundance of springs.
editor_notes: The WWF definition is somewhat ambiguous, but workable.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: freshwater biome|aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem|xeric basin biome|freshwater ecosystem

definitions: A biome which is determined by a water body and which has ecological climax communities adapted to life in or on water.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|aquatic ecosystem

definitions: The concentration basin mediterranean sea biome comprises expressions of the mediterranean sea biome that have higher salinity than bordering oceans due to evaporation. Water exchange consists of inflow of the fresher oceanic water in the upper layer and outflow of the saltier mediterranean water in the lower layer of the connecting channel.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|mediterranean sea biome|marine biome|concentration basin mediterranean sea biome|subtropical environment|marine ecosystem|subtropical biome|mediterranean biome

definitions: Expressions of the estuarine biome occur at wide lower courses of a rivers where they flow into a sea. Estuaries experience tidal flows and their water is a changing mixture of fresh and salt.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine biome|estuarine biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine salt marsh biome comprises marshes that are transitional intertidals between land and salty or brackish marine water (e.g.: sloughs, bays, estuaries). It is dominated by halophytic (salt tolerant) herbaceous plants. The daily tidal surges bring in nutrients, which tend to settle in roots of the plants within the salt marsh. The natural chemical activity of salty (or brackish) water and the tendency of algae to bloom in the shallow unshaded water also allow for great biodiversity.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine biome|marine salt marsh biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine pelagic biome (pelagic meaning open sea) is that of the marine water column, from the surface to the greatest depths.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The marine benthic biome (benthic meaning 'bottom') encompasses the seafloor and includes such areas as shores, littoral or intertidal areas, marine coral reefs, and the deep seabed.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine biome|marine benthic biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine neritic zone biome comprises sea floor from the high tide mark to a continental shelf break. This zone generally extends to 200 m below average sea level.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine neritic benthic zone biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine bathyal zone biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome between approximately 200 m and 3000 m depth. This zone generally coincides with the continental slope.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine benthic biome|marine biome|marine bathyal zone biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine abyssal zone biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome  between approximately 2500 m and 6000 m depth. This zone generally coincides with the continental rise and the abyssal plain.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine benthic biome|marine biome|marine abyssal zone biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine hadal zone biome describes sea floor deeper than 6000 m such as that of the oceanic trenches.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine benthic biome|marine biome|marine hadal zone biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: A biome expressed by strips or ridges of rocks, sand, or coral that rises to or near the surface of a body of marine water.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine benthic biome|marine reef biome|marine biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine hydrothermal vent biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome where heat generated due to tectonic activity, either at divergent plate boundaries or convergent ocean plates where back-arc spreading occurs, is released or 'vented' to the surface. The resultant high temperature water jets are laden with dissolved metals and minerals.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine benthic biome|marine hydrothermal vent biome|marine biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The neritic epipelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column above a continental shelf.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|neritic pelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The oceanic epipelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column offshore, beyond a continental shelf.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|oceanic pelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The oceanic sea surface microlayer (SML) biome comprises the top 1000 micrometers of the marine surface waters occurring offshore, away from a continental shelf. It is the boundary layer where all exchange occurs between the atmosphere and the ocean. The chemical, physical, and biological properties of the SML differ greatly from the sub-surface water just a few centimeters beneath.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic sea surface microlayer biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The oceanic epipelagic zone biome comprises regions of the marine water column that occur offshore, beyond a continental shelf. This biome extends from the surface of the ocean to a depth of ca. 200-250m. Throughout the zone the light field tends to be asymmetrical vertically, so that the direction and elevation of the sun can still be detected. The oceanic epipelagic zone biome encompasses the euphotic zone and, where and when it occurs, the seasonal thermocline.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic epipelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The oceanic mesopelagic zone biome comprises regions of the marine water column that occur offshore, beyond a continental shelf. This biome extends through the water column from approximately 200-1000 m depth - the maximal depth of light penetration in all but the clearest oligotrophic ocean regions. In comparison to the epipelagic zone, dominant forms of pelagic organisms do not change very much; however, there are marked changes in species composition and the proportion of smaller-sized individuals decreases.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic mesopelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The bathypelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column below approximately 1000 m water depth - the maximum depth to which detectable daylight penetrates in all but the clearest oligotrophic waters - and extends to about 2500 - 2700 m water depth. In the temperate Atlantic, the beginning of the bathypelagic zone biome approximates to the deep oxygen minimum and the base of the permanent thermocline.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic bathypelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The abyssopelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column below the bathypelagic zone biome at approximately 2500 -2700 m and extends either to the hadal pelagic zone biome (at approximately 6000 m) or to the benthopelagic zone biome within ca. 100 m of the seafloor. The depth of 2700 m may be critical for physiological reasons as the change in hydrostatic pressure across this depth may preclude organism migration.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic abyssopelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The oceanic hadal pelagic zone biome comprises the water column in oceanic trenches occurring at depths between 6000m and 10,000m.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic hadal pelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The benthopelagic zone biome comprises regions of the marine water column which usually coincide with the benthic boundary layer (BBL) - the layer of isothermal and isohaline water contiguous to the sea floor. A general reversal in the declining gradient of pelagic biomass may be observed here, perhaps explained by viable nutrition on the sea floor being resuspended by bottom currents. This zone typically extends 100 m above the seafloor, but may reach upto1000 m during benthic storms.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|oceanic pelagic zone biome|oceanic benthopelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The neritic sea surface microlayer (SML) biome comprises the top 1000 micrometers of marine surface waters occurring above a continental shelf. It is the boundary layer where all exchange occurs between the atmosphere and the ocean. The chemical, physical, and biological properties of the SML differ greatly from the sub-surface water just a few centimeters beneath.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|neritic pelagic zone biome|neritic sea surface microlayer biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The neritic epipelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column that occurs above a continental shelf and extends from the surface of the ocean to a depth of ca. 200-250m. Throughout the zone the light field tends to be asymmetrical vertically, so that the direction and elevation of the sun can still be detected. The epipelagic zone encompasses the euphotic zone and, where and when it occurs, the seasonal thermocline.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|neritic pelagic zone biome|neritic epipelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The neritic mesopelagic zone biome comprises the marine column that occurs above a continental shelf and extends from approximately 200 to 1000 m depth - the maximal depth of light penetration in all but the clearest oligotrophic ocean regions. In comparison to the epipelagic zone, dominant forms of pelagic organisms do not change very much; however, there are marked changes in species composition and the proportion of smaller-sized individuals decreases.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|neritic pelagic zone biome|neritic mesopelagic zone biome|marine biome|marine pelagic biome|marine ecosystem
overlaps: liquid water|marine water body|liquid environmental material

definitions: The epeiric sea (also known as an epicontinental sea) biome comprises a shallow seas that extend over part of a continent. Epeiric seas are usually associated with the marine transgressions of the geologic  past, which have variously been due to either global eustatic sea level changes, local tectonic deformation, or both, and are occasionally semi-cyclic.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine biome|epeiric sea biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marginal sea biome comprises parts of an ocean partially enclosed by land such as islands, archipelagos, or peninsulas. Unlike mediterranean seas, marginal seas have ocean currents caused by ocean winds. Many marginal seas are enclosed by island arcs that were formed from the subduction of one oceanic plate beneath another.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine biome|marginal sea biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The mediterranean sea biome comprises mostly enclosed seas that have limited exchange of deep water with outer oceans and where the water circulation is dominated by salinity and temperature differences rather than winds.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|mediterranean sea biome|marine biome|subtropical environment|subtropical biome|mediterranean biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

comments: Ocean biomes are determined by major bodies of saline water, principal components of the hydrosphere. Approximately 71% of the Earth's surface is covered by ocean, a continuous body of water that is customarily divided into several principal oceans and smaller seas. More than half of this area is over 3,000 metres (9,800 ft) deep. Average oceanic salinity is around 35 parts per thousand (ppt) (3.5%), and nearly all seawater has a salinity in the range of 30 to 38 ppt.
definitions: A marine biome which is determined by an ocean.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|marine biome|ocean biome|aquatic ecosystem|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine coral reef biome comprises constructional wave-resistant entities which are primarily built by corals and are often cemented together. The growth of these structures is aided by zooxanthellae, algae that are symbiotic with the reef-building corals.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine reef biome|marine coral reef biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine rocky subtidal reef biome comprises regions of the marine reef biome composed mainly of rock and which harbour abundant communities of algae and invertebrates. These reefs are often very patchy, with alterations of rocks dominated by rich invertebrate assemblages and turf-forming calcareous red algae.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine reef biome|marine subtidal rocky reef biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: A marine black smoker biome comprises regions of the marine hydrothermal vent biome characterised by a black vent plume. This black plume is a consequence of dissolved metals and minerals forming complexes with sulphide and indicates polymetallic sulphide mineral deposits beneath the surface.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine hydrothermal vent biome|marine black smoker biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: A marine white smoker biome comprises regions of the marine hydrothermal vent biome characterised by lightly hued plumes, typically containing barium, calcium, and silicon. These vents tend to have lower temperature plumes when compared to black smoker environments.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine hydrothermal vent biome|marine white smoker biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: A marine ultramafic hydrothermal vent biome comprises regions of themarine  hydrothermal vent biome hosted on ultramafic (also referred to as ultrabasic) rocks. Ultramafic rocks are igneous and meta-igneous rocks with very low silica content (less than 45%), generally >18% MgO, high FeO, low potassium, and are composed of usually greater than 90% mafic minerals  (dark colored, high magnesium and iron content). The Earth's mantle is composed of ultramafic rocks.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine hydrothermal vent biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ultramafic hydrothermal vent biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: A marine basaltic hydrothermal vent biome comprises regions of the marine hydrothermal vent biome hosted on basaltic rocks. Basalt generally has a composition of 45 to 55 wt % SiO2, 2 to 6 wt % total alkalis, 0.5 to 2.0 wt % TiO2, 5 to 14 wt % FeO and 14 wt % or more Al2O3. Contents of CaO are commonly near 10 wt %, those of MgO commonly in the range 5 to 12 wt %.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine hydrothermal vent biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine basaltic hydrothermal vent biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: The marine sponge reef biome comprises marine reefs primarily built by marine sponges. The primary frame-building sponges are all members of the order Hexactinosa. They are found only in glacier-scoured troughs of low-angle continental shelf. The seafloor is stable and consists of rock, coarse gravel, and large boulders.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine reef biome|marine sponge reef biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ecosystem

comments: The marine cold seep biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome where seepage of methane, hydrogen sulphide, hydrocarbon rich fluids and other fluids occurs.
definitions: A marine benthic biome which is determined by a cold seep.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|marine cold seep biome|marine biome|marine benthic biome|marine ecosystem

definitions: The dilution basin mediterranean sea biome comprises expressions of the mediterranean sea biome with lower salinity than the surrounding ocean due to freshwater gains such as rainfall and rivers. Water exchange consists of outflow of the fresher mediterranean water in the upper layer and inflow of the saltier oceanic water in the lower layer of the channel. Renewal of deep water may not be sufficient to supply oxygen to the bottom.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: aquatic biome|marine environment|aquatic ecosystem|mediterranean sea biome|dilution basin mediterranean sea biome|marine biome|subtropical environment|marine ecosystem|subtropical biome|mediterranean biome

definitions: A forest ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|forest biome|terrestrial ecosystem|forest ecosystem

comments: Preliminary definition.
definitions: A woodland biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its entire spatial extent, woody plants spaced sufficiently far apart to allow light penetration to support communities of herbaceous plants or shrubs living closer to the woodland floor.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem|woodland biome
overlaps: woodland area|terrestrial biome|vegetated area|terrestrial environmental zone|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: Preliminary definition.
definitions: A shrubland biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its entire spatial extent, dense groups of shrubs.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem|shrubland biome

definitions: A grassland ecosystem in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|grassland ecosystem|terrestrial ecosystem|grassland biome

definitions: A woodland biome which has seasonal water availability and includes trees spaced sufficiently far apart to allow an unbroken layer of grass, sedge (Cyperaceae) or  rush (Juncaceae) communities to live.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem|woodland biome|savanna biome
overlaps: woodland area|terrestrial biome|vegetated area|terrestrial environmental zone|terrestrial ecosystem

definitions: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: desert ecosystem|desert biome
overlaps: terrestrial biome|desert area|terrestrial environmental zone|desert|area of barren land|terrestrial ecosystem

definitions: A tundra ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem|tundra biome|tundra ecosystem
overlaps: soil|clay|sand|particulate environmental material|organic material|mineral material|particle of sand|particle of silt|terrestrial biome|silt|particle|particle of clay|area of tundra|vegetated area|terrestrial environmental zone|tundra biome|pedosphere|tundra ecosystem|frozen land|frozen soil|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: Preliminary definition. Depending on whether mangrove trees or shrubs are present, this class could be a child of shrubland biome or woodland biome. Consider creating the appropriate classes.
definitions: A mangrove biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its spatial extent, mangrove plants (Rhizophoraceae). Mangrove plants are able to withstand high levels of salinity as well as regions of anoxia and frequent tidal inundation. Mangrove biomes often occur near tropical and sub-tropical estuaries and depositional marine coastal environments where fine sediments (often with high organic content) collect in areas protected from high energy wave action.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem|mangrove biome
overlaps: soil|clay|sand|particulate environmental material|organic material|mineral material|particle of sand|particle of silt|silt|particle|particle of clay|mangrove swamp|coastal wetland ecosystem|sea coast|pedosphere|wetland ecosystem|coast|soil surface layer|soil layer

comments: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.
definitions: A temperate desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to intermediate insolation, low rainfall, and large temperature variations between winter and summer. Winter temperatures may fall below 0 degrees Celsius. Some precipitation in this biome may fall as snow.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: temperate biome|temperate environment|desert ecosystem|desert biome|temperate desert biome
overlaps: terrestrial biome|desert area|terrestrial environmental zone|desert|area of barren land|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.
definitions: A tropical desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to temperatures above a monthly average of 18 degrees Celsius, high daily temperature ranges of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, very high insolation due to inhibited cloud formation, and very low precipitation. Tropical desert biomes located near coasts with cold upwellings may have cooler temperatures and reduced insolution due to fog.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: tropical environment|desert ecosystem|tropical biome|desert biome|tropical desert biome
overlaps: terrestrial biome|desert area|terrestrial environmental zone|desert|area of barren land|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.
definitions: A subtropical desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to temperatures above a monthly average of 18 degrees Celsius, high daily temperature ranges of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, high insolation (but lower than that of a tropical desert biome), inhibited cloud formation, and very low precipitation. Subtropical desert biomes located near coasts with cold upwellings may have cooler temperatures and reduced insolution due to fog.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: desert ecosystem|desert biome|subtropical desert biome|subtropical environment|subtropical biome
overlaps: terrestrial biome|desert area|terrestrial environmental zone|desert|area of barren land|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: Preliminary definition.
definitions: A montane desert biome is a desert biome which occurs in regions elevated above sea level and which has community structure determined by elevation-dependent environmental conditions.

comments: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.
definitions: A polar desert biome is a desert biome which is subject to low levels of insolation, annual precipitation less than 250 millimeters, and a mean temperature less than 10 degrees Celsius during its warmest month. Temperature changes in polar deserts frequently cross the freezing point of water.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: polar biome|polar environment|desert ecosystem|desert biome|polar desert biome
overlaps: terrestrial biome|desert area|terrestrial environmental zone|desert|area of barren land|terrestrial ecosystem

comments: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions. CMECS provides the following notes: "Commonly found on intertidal mud flats along the shores of estuaries. Tidal mangrove shrublands may include immature stands or stunted mature trees that indicate a harsh growing environment. Areas characterized by tall mangroves (> 6 meters) are placed in the Tidal Mangrove Forest Biotic Group. Where tidal amplitude is relatively low, the vegetation forms narrow bands along the coastal plains, and it rarely penetrates inland more than several kilometers along rivers. Where tidal amplitude is greater, mangroves extend further inland along river courses, forming extensive stands in the major river deltas. Also, mangrove cays may occur within the lagoon complex of barrier reefs. The list of biotic communities for this group is long: a few examples are provided below, and the complete list is available in Appendix F"
definitions: A shrubland biome which is densely vegetated by dwarf or short mangroves (and associates) that are generally less than 6 meters in height, is tidally influenced,  is located in tropical or subtropical areas.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: tidal mangrove shrubland|terrestrial biome|terrestrial ecosystem|shrubland biome
overlaps: clay|soil|sand|particulate environmental material|organic material|mineral material|particle of sand|particle of silt|terrestrial biome|silt|particle|particle of clay|mangrove swamp|mangrove biome|coastal wetland ecosystem|sea coast|pedosphere|wetland ecosystem|coast|terrestrial ecosystem|soil surface layer|soil layer

comments: The absence of trees in this biome is primarily due to high altitude rather than high latitude. On Earth, it lies roughly between the summer isotherm of 10 degrees Centigrade and the snow line. Primary productivity is low in this biome because of the extremes of climate.
definitions: A tundra biome which exists at high altitudes and where vegetation - dominated by a few species of dwarf shrubs, a few grasses, sedges, lichens, and mosses - is stunted due to low temperatures and high winds.
http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#sub: alpine tundra biome|terrestrial biome|tundra biome|terrestrial ecosystem|tundra ecosystem|alpine biome
